Oliver Coleman's new Java-based HyperNEAT package "AHNI" (which is an ext=
ension of ANJI) is now served from our group and the link is available from=
 the software section of the HyperNEAT Users page.  The link is:

http://ep=
lex.cs.ucf.edu/software/ahni.tar.bz2

Also, I've looked over most of Oliver=
's thesis and I recommend reading it to anyone in the group interested in H=
yperNEAT.  The visual processing experiments are quite interesting and the =
visualizations of evolved receptor field layouts provide a lot of insight. =
 They turn out to be surprisingly well-organized.  The visual processing ca=
pabilities of HyperNEAT had not been previously explored much beyond the ol=
d boxes domain; the new results suggest there is a lot of potential for int=
eresting structures to emerge in this kind of domain.

Thanks very much to =
Oliver for providing a new HyperNEAT package for Java as well.

ken

--- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman <oliver@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> =
I've recently completed a thesis on some of the properties and 
> character=
istics of HyperNEAT. The abstract is below; the thesis is 
> attached. As p=
art of this work I created a Java implementation of 
> HyperNEAT, it is cur=
rently available on the NEAT group page in the files 
> section and should =
soon be up on the HyperNEAT User's Page (when Ken 
> gets around to it).
> =

> Cheers,
> Oliver
> 
> Abstract:
> 
> In this study a recently developed =
neuroevolution method, HyperNEAT, is
> applied to new tasks in order to lea=
rn more about its characteristics in
> general and for the tasks specifical=
ly. The tasks required directly
> processing raw image data, including some=
 from a robot-mounted camera,
> requiring the neural networks to directly p=
rocess hundreds or thousands
> of inputs. The tasks included object recogni=
tion and robot navigation.
> The complexity and properties of the tasks, as=
 well as the neural
> network substrate topologies, were varied and the per=
formance and
> characteristics of the evolutionary process and solutions ge=
nerated were
> analysed. Positive results were achieved for non-trivial tas=
ks, and some
> important characteristics of HyperNEAT not previously report=
ed were
> discovered: a bias towards generating weight patterns aligned wit=
h the
> topographical arrangement of neurons within the layers of the subst=
rate
> network; the impact on performance of the number of dimensions in th=
e
> topographical arrangement of neurons in hidden layers; the ability to
>=
 evolve solutions more quickly with larger substrate networks; and a
> poss=
ible difficulty co-evolving weight patterns for substrate networks
> contai=
ning more than one hidden layer. New directions for further
> research and =
possible enhancements to HyperNEAT are proposed based on
> these findings.
=
> 
>
